message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and spirometry results suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Albuterol before exercise can be used as a first-line treatment. Prednisone therapy is not indicated for exercise-induced bronchoconstriction. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not useful for this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB) and spirometry shows normal lung function, ruling out asthma. Albuterol before exercise is a first-line treatment for EIB. Prednisone therapy is not indicated for EIB. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not relevant to the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and spirometry results suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which can be treated with a short-acting bronchodilator such as albuterol before exercise. Prednisone therapy, genetic testing, and echocardiography are not indicated for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and spirometry results suggest exercise-induced asthma. Albuterol before exercise is the most appropriate initial management for exercise-induced asthma. Prednisone therapy is not recommended for mild to moderate exercise-induced asthma. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not indicated based on the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has exercise-induced bronchoconstriction, which can be treated with a short-acting beta-agonist such as albuterol before exercise. Prednisone therapy is not indicated. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not relevant to the diagnosis and management of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest exercise-induced asthma, and spirometry shows a slightly decreased FEV1. Albuterol before exercise is a first-line treatment for exercise-induced asthma. Prednisone therapy is not indicated at this time, as the patient's symptoms are not severe enough to warrant systemic corticosteroids. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not indicated based on the information provided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and normal spirometry results suggest exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB). Albuterol before exercise is the first-line treatment for EIB. Prednisone therapy is not indicated in this scenario. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not relevant to the diagnosis or management of EIB.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of exercise-induced asthma, and spirometry shows a mild reduction in FEV1, suggesting mild asthma. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to prescribe albuterol before exercise to prevent symptoms. Prednisone therapy is not necessary at this point, and genetic testing and echocardiography are not indicated in this case.

Prednisone therapy is not necessary as there are no signs of asthma or inflammation. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not indicated based on the symptoms and findings.

The patient presents with symptoms characteristic of exercise-induced bronchoconstriction (EIB), and spirometry shows only slightly reduced lung function. Albuterol before exercise is the most appropriate step to manage EIB. Prednisone therapy is not recommended as first-line treatment for EIB. Genetic testing and echocardiography are not indicated in this case.
